content.content: Decentralization and transparency are meant to solve the issue of withheld information, but they neglect to solve the issue of overabundant information. As the crypto market grows in adoption and accelerates post-Merge, Maker must implement a thorough information digestion system to attenuate the amount of data and news that must be mentally sorted out by each member of the organization – especially as we are considering spinning off into more discrete groups. ( My comment below talks about the historical problems of overstimulation in the tech industry. ) MOOGLES Imagine a Maker where we have devised a network of impartial correspondents, each with their particular “beat” or section of Maker that they track and provide summary for (for instance, a “Moogle” for every two or three metaDAOs). They could meet together monthly over Zoom, presenting an account of each section of the DAO, as a sort of public global check-in. In addition, they could be required to pen a forum summary for their “beat” on a weekly basis, run some sort of Q&A, or generally be the go-to person for consultation about that part of the DAO. ( Moogle refers to the synthesis-service-providing creatures in Kingdom Hearts (also Final Fantasy), but could also mean “Maker Google.”  ) BENEFITS For example, a UI designer could confer with the “Dev/Oracle Moogle” to find out how the end user would want to interact with a given product, so they can get to the actual designing much faster than if they had to become fairly knowledgeable about the inner workings of a product, just to make its interface. Or, a delegate could consult the same Moogle to learn more about what impact a particular vote would have on oracles, in lieu of abstaining or voting without certainty. Informational clarity would be at its peak, and across the board Maker could be making the most informed possible decisions, with the most efficient mental energy cost.

content.content: In philosopher Franco “Bifo” Berardi’s “Time, Acceleration, and Violence,” Bifo posits that the dot-com crash was in part due to workers’ attentions being overstrained. He points out that the use of amphetamines and Prozac that characterized the 90s was in decline when the crash happened, suggesting that the drugs were used in part to match the attention levels and “irrational exuberance” required of the markets at the time. In their absence, the industry could no longer maintain its pumped up state. If we can work out our communications systems, we can avoid this strain and provide even more stability for Maker, especially in an industry that’s already overflowing with stimulation before mass adoption.

content.content: If the Moogles each shared one CU/metaDAO with one other Moogle, their reports should come out basically identical. We should be able to use this expected parity to some advantage. If the parameters of these reports are agreed upon for each CU ahead of time, an auditor Moogle could easily go through and look for any significant disparities. The auditor should be blind to which report is whose beforehand. Actually, any Moogle could audit any other two Moogle’s reports. If everything is working as it should, they should basically just check off the reports, and it shouldn’t matter which one gets published. It’s a fairly organized affair but incentivizes removing spin from what’s essentially a history of the organization. And if the auditing Moogle spots something and that leads to one of the reports changing, that could cut a portion of compensation for the Moogle whose report changed. Perhaps pay in DAI like a regular salary and then there’s some vesting MKR as well, and that’s the part that would diminish.
